headline: Controversial Resource Management Bill Passes Final Hurdle Amid Environmental and Procedural Protests
summary: Parliament saw the final passage of a contentious bill to overhaul resource management laws, a move the government says will fast-track development but which opponents claim weakens crucial environmental protections through a rushed process. The day was also marked by tense exchanges during Question Time over rising Pasifika unemployment, job losses in the science sector, and New Zealand's delayed decision on recognizing Palestinian statehood.

topicSummaries.topic: Resource Management Bill Passes Third Reading, Easing Rules for Development and Fossil Fuels
topicSummaries.content: The Resource Management (Consenting and Other System Changes) Amendment Bill passed its third and final reading, backed by the government coalition. Minister Chris Bishop championed the bill as a necessary step to "unclog the arteries of growth" by simplifying consenting for infrastructure, housing, and the primary sector. However, the bill lost its earlier cross-party support after the government introduced last-minute amendments that were not subject to public consultation. Opposition parties heavily criticized these changes, which streamline consenting for thermal electricity generation (coal and gas) and weaken protections against discharging contaminants into waterways, arguing the process was undemocratic and harmful to the environment.

keyExchanges.speaker: Hon CHRIS BISHOP (National)
keyExchanges.quote: What we've been trying to do throughout the programme of reform is achieve some quick wins to make sure we can unclog the arteries of growth in our economy while we lay the foundations for the full-scale reform of the RMA, and this is one of those ones that creates targeted changes that will make a difference.

keyExchanges.speaker: Hon RACHEL BROOKING (Labour)
keyExchanges.quote: This is a terrible way to make laws. This House has to spend so much time tidying up the mistakes of this Government that are made hastily, that do not go through select committees, and that members only see on the day that we are going into the committee stage.

topicSummaries.topic: Minister Grilled Over Doubling of Pasifika Unemployment and Funding Cuts
topicSummaries.content: A sharp exchange occurred during Question Time over the economic situation for Pacific peoples. Labour's Carmel Sepuloni challenged the Minister for Pacific Peoples, Dr Shane Reti, on why Pasifika unemployment has doubled to 12% since the government took office. Sepuloni questioned the logic of cutting $22 million from the Tupu Aotearoa Pacific employment programme amidst rising joblessness. Dr Reti defended the government's strategy, attributing the unemployment figures to inherited economic conditions and stating the funding changes would allow for better collaboration with the Ministry of Social Development to deliver more focused outcomes.

keyExchanges.speaker: Hon Carmel Sepuloni (Labour)
keyExchanges.quote: Why did he cut $22 million out of the Tupu Aotearoa Pacific employment and training programme at a time when Pasifika unemployment is more than twice the national average?

keyExchanges.speaker: Hon Dr SHANE RETI (National)
keyExchanges.quote: What we're wanting to do with Tupu Aotearoa is collaborate with the Ministry of Social Development (MSD), who have similar programmes, and we wanted to enhance the benefits we saw from Tupu Aotearoa in the last financial year, that delivered 2,551 outcomes. We believe we can do a better job in collaboration with MSD.

topicSummaries.topic: Government Defends Delay on Recognizing Palestinian Statehood Amid Cabinet Division Questions
topicSummaries.content: Foreign policy came under scrutiny as Green MP Teanau Tuiono questioned why New Zealand has not yet joined allies like Australia, Canada, and the UK in recognizing Palestinian statehood. Tuiono pointed to media reports suggesting ACT Party Ministers had blocked the move in Cabinet. Acting Foreign Affairs Minister Todd McClay refused to comment on Cabinet discussions but insisted the government was united in its approach. He stated the government would not be rushed into a decision by "political grandstanding" and would take the appropriate time to consider all information.

keyExchanges.speaker: Teanau Tuiono (Green)
keyExchanges.quote: Can he confirm media reports that the reason New Zealand is yet to recognise Palestinian statehood, despite commitments from France, the UK, Canada, and Australia, is because ACT Ministers stopped it at Monday's Cabinet meeting?

keyExchanges.speaker: Hon TODD McCLAY (National)
keyExchanges.quote: I'm not going to talk about what happened in Cabinet, but it is very clear that the Government is united in making sure that we make the decision that's not only right but right for New Zealand. We are going to consider all of the information before us, and we won't be doing—as some members of this Parliament do—grandstanding and rushing to a decision.

topicSummaries.topic: Bill to Speed Up Land Acquisition for Major Projects Advances
topicSummaries.content: The Public Works (Critical Infrastructure) Amendment Bill passed its second reading with support from National, ACT, NZ First, and Labour. The bill aims to accelerate land acquisition for critical infrastructure projects, such as roads of national significance, by replacing Environment Court appeals with a written submission process to the responsible Minister and offering incentive payments to landowners for early agreement. The Green Party strongly opposed the bill, citing concerns over the removal of appeal rights and the potential impact on landowners' connection to their whenua. Labour, while supporting the bill's progression, also raised concerns about the lack of an independent appeal process.

keyExchanges.speaker: Hon CHRIS PENK (National)
keyExchanges.quote: New Zealand needs and deserves critical infrastructure to be delivered faster, to support its growth in the economy, and I believe that we are achieving a faster and fairer regime through the amendments suggested by the select committee and the legislation itself.

keyExchanges.speaker: Hon JULIE ANNE GENTER (Green)
keyExchanges.quote: It's deeply ironic to me that a Government that proposes—or purports—to care about property rights is at the same time making decisions to make it easier to take away those property rights. And of course, when we're talking about land and a relationship to whenua, that is much deeper than some sort of financial interest and property.

conclusion: The government successfully advanced its pro-development agenda, while facing sustained criticism over the environmental consequences, erosion of public process, and negative social outcomes for vulnerable communities.
